data.text:
Many sports management degree programs in South Carolina can provide the latitude for achieving your dream athletics career. Nestled between the Blue Ridge Mountains and Atlantic Ocean, South Carolina is the country’s 23rd most populous state with 4.8 million residents. The Palmetto State has a thriving economy with a GSP of $153 billion. Manufacturing may consist of 42.3 percent of South Carolina’s revenue, but sports and tourism is a growing sector. The NFL Carolina Panthers have a top-notch training facility in Spartanburg.

Minor league teams include the Charleston Battery, South Carolina Stingrays, Greenville Swamp Rabbits, and Myrtle Beach Pelicans. College sports rivalries are epic between the USC Gamecocks and Clemson Tigers. South Carolina’s Darlington Raceway has also hosted several notable NASCAR races. To see more sports management degree programs, visit Sports Management Degree Programs in South Carolina (N-Z).

Claflin University

School of Education

Established in 1869 by northern missionaries, Claflin University is a private, co-educational liberal arts institution affiliated with the United Methodist Church to educate over 1,800 students from its 40-acre urban campus in Orangeburg just 40 miles southeast of the state’s capital. With a student-faculty ratio of 14:1, Claflin University is ranked the 174th best national liberal arts college and eighth top HBCU by the U.S. News. The Claflin Panthers compete in the NCAA Division II Southern Intercollegiate Athletic Conference with 10 varsity teams. In the School of Education, students can select from NCATE-accredited programs for engaged training.

Bachelor of Science in Sport Management

At Claflin, the Bachelor of Science in Sport Management is an upper-division program offered to juniors who have completed 60 semester hours with a minimum 2.5 GPA. Upon admittance, students will develop a broad-based core of knowledge in sports business to become highly educated managers in professional, amateur, collegiate, or youth sports. The 60-hour major makes certain undergraduates have the management style to organize sporting events with sound, diverse business practices. All undergraduates are encouraged to complete a 60-day senior internship at sports clubs in Greater Orangeburg. High-achieving B.S. majors could also challenge themselves in the Alice Carson Tisdale Honors College.

Clemson University

College of Health, Education and Human Development

Enrolling over 22,600 students, Clemson University is a selective public, co-educational research institution with sea-grant and land-grant status to operate six colleges from a vast 17,000-acre rural campus just 27 miles west of downtown Greenville along the Blue Ridge foothills. Highly regarded for having the ACC’s second largest stadium, the Clemson Tigers house 17 NCAA Division I teams and four national championship titles. According to the U.S. News, Clemson is the 61st best national university, 21st top public school, and 16th most innovative college. The College of Health, Education and Human Development was created in 1995 to become an award-winning “Engaged College with a Personal Touch.”

PRTM Degree with Community Recreation, Sport, and Camp Management Concentration

For a Bachelor of Science, Clemson offers a Parks, Recreation, Tourism Management (PRTM) degree with seven specialized concentrations, including Community Recreation, Sport, and Camp Management (CRSCM). Undergraduates following this track will customize their 120-credit curriculum for taking on managerial positions in the public and non-profit sectors of recreation. Students benefit from participating in a semester-long PRTM EDGE program that breaks down classroom walls with diverse, guided learning experiences. In addition, there’s a required 400-hour senior internship for working in amateur sports or camps. Students can join the South Carolina Recreation and Parks Association (SCRPA) for networking too.

Coastal Carolina University

College of Science

Gaining independence in 1993, Coastal Carolina University is now a public, state-funded liberal arts institution with sea-grant status to educate over 10,200 students from its 630-acre suburban campus in Conway just a half hour from the Atlantic Ocean. From the LEED-certified HTC Center, the CCU Chanticleers have eight men’s and nine women’s varsity teams competing in the NCAA Division I Sun Belt Conference. Coastal is currently ranked the 63rd best college, 26th top public school, and sixth best value university in the South by the U.S. News. The College of Science houses 17 bachelor’s programs ranging from mathematics and information technology to biology and public health.

B.S. in Recreation and Sport Management (RSM)

The B.S. in Recreation and Sport Management (RSM) program at Coastal takes a career-oriented approach to developing skills and theories that transfer directly to the sports business workplace. Within the 58-credit major, students gain a breadth of knowledge in event planning, facility management, research methods, risk management, budgeting, advertising, personnel management, and project management. Outside the classroom, students participate in hands-on, field-based projects. RSM majors can conduct research in the Exergaming Lab, Exercise Physiology Lab, or Strength Training Lab. CCU is conveniently located near Myrtle Beach, which was voted “Sportstown USA” by Sports Illustrated. Numerous local agencies can help satisfy the program’s 480-hour internship requirement. There’s also a B.S. in Exercise and Sport Science available.

Erskine College

Located on a 90-acre rural campus in Due West within 16 miles from Greenwood, Erskine College is an accredited private, non-profit Christian liberal arts institution offering bachelor’s programs affiliated with the Associate Reformed Presbyterian Church. The Erskine Flying Fleet competes in the NCAA Division II Conference Carolinas with 15 varsity teams from lacrosse to basketball. With an enrollment of 575 students, Erskine College is ranked the 292nd best private college nationally and 93rd top school in the South by Forbes magazine. High school counselors surveyed by the U.S. News rated Erskine the 137th best liberal arts college.

Sports Management Major

Ideal for students passionate about nutrition and fitness, the Sports Management Major leads to a Bachelor of Science degree at Erskine College. The 120-credit curriculum equips undergrad learners with in-depth insight into the science of health and the business of sports. With a student-faculty ratio of 12:1, class sizes are kept under 20 for close peer and professor interaction. Coursework immerses students into understanding today’s topics in sports marketing, arena management, event planning, coaching, fitness center management, wellness, and entrepreneurship. Partnerships with the University of St. Andrews and Oxford University allows for study abroad options in the United Kingdom. Erskine also offers a CAATE-accredited Athletic Training Major for becoming eligible for the BOC Exam.

Limestone College

Education and Physical Education Division

Founded by Thomas Curtis and his son William in 1845, Limestone College is a private, four-year non-denominational Christian liberal arts institution enlightening over 3,500 students from its historic 125-acre suburban campus in Gaffney, the “Peach Capital of South Carolina.” The Limestone Saints compete in the NCAA Division II Conference Carolinas with 22 varsity teams, including the 2000 and 2002 men’s national lacrosse champions. The U.S. News ranks LC as the 73rd best regional college and 40th top school for veterans in the South. The Education and Physical Education Division offers bachelor’s in elementary, early childhood, physical education, athletic training, and sport management.

Bachelor of Science in Sport Management

Delivered in a traditional daytime format, the Bachelor of Science in Sport Management program at Limestone College lays the foundation of fundamental skills for gaining entry-level sports business positions. The interdisciplinary majors blends courses from business administration and physical education for jobs in a fast-growing field. For 123 total credits, students engage in courses on financial accounting, marketing, management theory, statistics, microeconomics, sport literature, sports history, fitness, and health education. Students benefit from participating in the Christian Education & Leadership Program (CLEP) with service learning projects, such as Stop Hunger Now and LC2 Tutoring. During the senior year, B.S. majors also complete a semester-long internship in the sports industry.

Newberry College

Department of Sport Professions

Affiliated with the Evangelical Lutheran Church of America (ELCA), Newberry College is an independent, co-educational liberal arts institution endowed for $23 million to serve over 1,000 students from its 90-acre urban campus in Newberry just 43 miles from Columbia. From wrestling to cross country, the Newberry Wolves compete for 17 varsity teams in the South Atlantic Conference of NCAA Division II. According to the U.S. News, Newberry is the 41st best college and 28th top school for military veterans in the South. The Department of Sport Professions offers concentrations in leisure services, sport management, and physical education.

B.S. Physical Education with Sport Management Concentration

Emphasizing rigor through research, the B.S. Physical Education with Sport Management Concentration allows Newberry students to prepare for lifelong intellectual development and careers behind the scenes in sports-related organizations. Students learn the ethical, professional behavior to turn a passion for sports into a viable career path. Within the 120-credit curriculum, students spend four to five years full-time actively involved in campus life. Hands-on experience is available managing the Smith Road Complex, Eleazer Arena, Setzler Field, and Cannon Courts. B.S. students can follow tracks leading to Praxis exams and PreK-12 certification or focus on the private/non-profit sector. Minors are granted in Coaching, Athletic Training, and Health.

Scoring a touchdown with an excellent sports management position is much tougher without a quality college education. Investing in four-plus years of tuition may not sound worthy, but the degree pays off in the world’s $1.5-trillion sports market. Employers look for visionary leaders with the training and experience to effectively handle the business side of sports. Even though you won’t be shooting three-pointers, you’ll work diligently behind the scenes to keep sports-related organizations afloat. Your degree will also be in high demand since certain sports career paths are growing by up to 21 percent through 2024. Add muscle to your resume by pursuing one of these sports management degree programs in South Carolina.
